question: 後ろ
sourceMnemonic: The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While <ja>後で</ja> (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: <vocabulary>behind</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>back</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>rear</vocabulary>. Think of the <ja>ろ</ja> as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (<ja>ろ</ja>) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind."
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Continue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look <vocabulary>behind</vocabulary> you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? It's <ja>うし</ja>, which is also the reading for this word.
